column3: Ante-Purgatory. Still with the Excommunicates; then, on the First Spur, with the Late-Repentant through negligence. Plato’s doctrine of the plurality of souls refuted by Dante’s experience. The hard climb to the First Spur. Virgil’s explanation of the sun’s path in the southern hemisphere. Belacqua, Dante’s friend. Noon.

Sometimes he is obsessively periphrastic; at a pole far from plain style (and Dante experiments with all styles), he lets us know that it is 3 p.m., the beginning of vespers, “there” in Purgatory by a likeness that measures the morning span between 6 a.m. and 9 a.m.: “As many as the hours in which the sphere / that’s always playing like a child appears / from daybreak to the end of the third hour, / so many were the hours of light still left / before the course of day had reached sunset; / vespers was there; and where we are, midnight” (XV, 1–6).

Dante’s need to array thirsts and hungerings and longings is as “limitless” as his thirst for the waters of Eunoe in the final canto (XXXIII, 138–139). When Dante receives an answer, he continues: “I am more hungry now for satisfaction” (XV, 58). His soul tastes “that food which, even as / it quenches hunger, spurs the appetite” (XXXI, 129–130). He is “still goaded by new thirst” (XVIII, 4). Reluctantly, he draws his “unquenchable sponge out of the water” (XX, 3). “A thousand longings burning more than flames” compel his eyes (XXXI, 118). Guido Guinizzelli burns for an answer “in fire and thirst” and lets Dante know that Guinizzelli’s fellow shades thirst for that answer “more than / an Indian or Ethiopian / thirsts for cool water” (XXVI, 18–22). When Dante asks the Muses for recompense (“O Virgins, sacrosanct, if I have ever, / for your sake, suffered vigils, cold, and hunger, / great need makes me entreat my recompense”: XXIX, 37–39), the hunger seems not only the hunger of indigent exile but the hungering and thirsting of this work.

1–6   These opening lines, which once again remind us of the global dimensions of Dante’s journey, depend on his envisioning Jerusalem, in the northern hemisphere, as directly opposite the island mountain of Purgatory in the southern hemisphere—exactly twelve hours apart from it in time (see diagram, and Intro). Thus, Jerusalem’s sunset coincides with sunrise in Purgatory. In relation to Jerusalem, the Ganges River in India marks the eastern horizon, the easternmost point of the inhabited world, while the westernmost horizon is marked by the Straits of Gibraltar (the “boundary stones of Hercules,” Inf. XXVI, 108) between Spain and Morocco—though Dante will sometimes refer to that westernmost point as the Ebro River (Purg. XXVII, 2) or Cadiz (Par. XXVIII, 82) or Morocco (Purg. IV, 139). His Earth clock thus has four principal stations: Jerusalem, the Ganges River, Purgatory, the Straits of Gibraltar. With Jerusalem at 6 P.M., it is midnight at the Ganges, 6 A.M. in Purgatory, and noon over the Straits of Gibraltar. (At times, Dante will also use Italy as a reference point, three hours earlier than Jerusalem, three hours later than the Straits of Gibraltar. See III, 25 and note and XV, 6 and note.) 91–96   “Ah you” is addressed to those holding Church office. For Dante they, instead of usurping temporal power and laying their hands “upon the bit,” should allow an emperor to sit “in the saddle.” “What God ordained” is, in Christ’s words, “Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar’s; and unto God the things that are God’s” (Matt. 22:21). For Dante’s view of the just relation between temporal and spiritual power, see his Monarchy and the essay “Dante in His Age” in the Bantam Classics Inferno. (For a translation of Dante’s Monarchia—Monarchy—see the entry under Nicholl in the bibliographical note at the end of these canto notes, or see the translation by H. W. Schneider, under the title On World-Government, New York, 1957.) [return to English / Italian]

13   “Te lucis ante,” a Compline hymn, known in English as “Before the ending of the day,” is a prayer asking God the Creator to defend us from evil and troubling dreams, and from any pollution that might come to us once we have dropped the guard of consciousness. Since in this canto we meet those who were too preoccupied with worldly affairs, their singing of this hymn may signify a redoubled vigilance that would guard against the entry of even the least willful kind of sin. But the souls in Ante-Purgatory are saved and essentially beyond temptation. Thus, they may be singing this hymn not for themselves but, out of compassion, for the living (see XI, 19–24). In the first two tercets, Aurora, concubine (“she who shares the bed”) of old Tithonus, was now rising in the northern hemisphere, in Italy, with the constellation Scorpio facing her as she rose. Thus, in Italy, it was about 5 A.M.; in Jerusalem it was about 8:30–9 A.M.; and in Purgatory it was about 8:30–9 P.M. The third tercet tells the time in Purgatory (“where we were”). Night is divided into twelve hours, six before midnight, six after. Two of these hours or “steps” (8) had already passed, and the third was about to complete its passage, which brought the time close to 9 P.M.

“Vespers” is one of the four three-hour periods, each named for the hour with which it finished, into which it was customary to divide the day from dawn to sunset: tierce, from the third hour (i.e., from 6 to 9 A.M.); sext, from the fourth to the sixth (i.e., from 9 A.M. to noon); none, from the seventh to the ninth (i.e., from noon to 3 P.M.); and vespers, from the ninth to the twelfth (i.e., from 3 to 6 P.M.). (The shift of meaning of none or nones from 3 P.M. to midday is institutionalized in the English language, for the word noon was originally simply an alternative spelling of the same word.)

As Dante notes (Conv. III, vi, 2–3), there are two modes of measuring the hours: the “temporal hours…used by the Church” are hours that divide day and night into twelve hours each, hours that increase or diminish in length as the length of day and night, respectively, diminishes or increases with changing seasons; the other mode measures “equal hours,” dividing the sum of day and night, whatever the respective length of day and night, into twenty-four equal hours. For the Church, the four daytime hours listed above (tierce, sext, none, and vespers) would be supplemented by three additional predaylight or postdaylight hours: matins with lauds (see Purg. I, 115–117, note); prime, the hour of sunrise; and compline (see Purg. VIII, 1–6 and 13, note). Together, these formed the seven canonical hours, times of day canonically appointed for offices of devotion. Since Dante places his journey so close to the vernal equinox, the discrepancy between “temporal hours” and “equal hours” is of little account in the Comedy.

1–3   At noon in this season the sun is over Purgatory in Aries. It enters Taurus two hours later. In the northern hemisphere the sign opposed to Aries, namely, Libra, gives way to Scorpio at the same time. This astronomical circumlocution means that it is approximately 2 P.M. on the afternoon of Easter Tuesday here in Purgatory, while at Jerusalem it is 2 A.M. There can be no pausing, for the day is two-thirds of the way toward its end; only four hours of daylight are left. [return to English / Italian]

43–51   At first, because of the distortion brought about by its great distance from the viewers, the source of the unusual light that fills the forest is wrongly identified as seven golden trees. The sense of lines 46–47 is clearer if we recall that Dante subscribed to a theory of perception that distinguished brightness and color, the “proper objects” of sight, about which it cannot err, from such secondary features as size, shape, number, movement and motionlessness, etc., which were considered the “common objects” of perception—common, that is, to several “mingled senses” (47). As they approach, and as Dante and Matilda advance toward them, the outlines of the bright objects become clearer, and Dante’s power of perception—the power that presents sense impressions to the brain, “the power that offers reason matter” (49)—judged them correctly to be seven lighted candelabra. (Though he earlier took them for trees, other details of the vision suggest that Dante may have had in mind not seven branching candelabra, but seven candlesticks, each with a single lit candle. The Latin version of the Book of Revelation, which could be said to contain the seed of his invention, has the word candelabra, which is translated in the King James version as “candlesticks”: “And I turned to see the voice that spake within me. And being turned, I saw seven golden candlesticks” [Rev. 1:12].) At the same time as the form of the candelabra becomes unmistakable, and for the same reason, what had seemed at first a melody (23) and then distinctly a song (36) becomes to Dante’s ear an intelligible sequence of syllables forming the Hebrew word “Hosanna,” the cry with which the multitude greeted Christ as he entered Jerusalem on the occasion commemorated on Palm Sunday (see Matt. 21:9). 105–106   After the assurance from Beatrice that he is one of the elect, Dante is invested with his poetic and prophetic mission. Until now, his journey might have seemed to be directed to his personal salvation; now its universal, exemplary aspect becomes explicit. St. John, too, was instructed more than once to record the contents of his vision. (See, for example, Rev. 1:11: “What thou seest, write in a book.”) Beatrice’s words to Dante—her first since she instructed him to raise his downcast head and look upon her, midway through Canto XXXI (67–69)—mark the beginning of yet another “act” in the symbolic drama of sacred history. This final act traces the vicissitudes of the historical Church from the early persecutions to the present day. [return to English / Italian]

It is into this full sun that Beatrice will gaze as the journey of Paradiso starts, while Dante, who is facing her, will gaze at the reflection of the sun in her eyes. We are reminded that ever since it first rose over the shoulders of the mountain in Inferno I, the sun has often served as a symbol of God and of the illumination of Divine Wisdom.
